results.title: Faces in the sun
results.creator_credit: Methodist Overseas Mission, Richard Mason and Cecil Holmes
results.brief_description: The story of four aboriginals grappling with assimilation pressures and facing a changing future. Through the experience of a bark painter, a teaching assistant, a carpenter, and a tribal headman, we see the type of life each one lives, and the conflict of the old and the new which sets up tensions within each one, and in Aboriginal society. (Award: Gold Award, General Category, Australian Film Awards, 1965).

results.title: Faces 1976–1996
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white, silent
results.brief_description:
In “Faces 1976–1996”, Sue Ford returned to the subjects of her seminal 1970s work “Faces” twenty years later. In collaboration with her son Ben Ford, the artist filmed her friends in the same format, framed in close-up with the camera trained on them for 25 seconds each, and presented the images in a multi-channel installation. Reflecting the artist’s interest in the camera’s ability to capture time, “Faces 1976–1996” shows the effect of time and change, and reveals the striking differences and inherent sameness on a person’s countenance.

Participants include artists Micky Allan, Bonita Ely and Paul Reed, among others.

results.title: Faces
results.creator_credit: Walter Reade Organization, Maurice McEndree and John Cassavetes
results.brief_description: Faces concentrates on two scenarios, one where middle-aged businessmen cheat on their wives and the other where the wives bring home a younger man from a nightclub. Both wives and husbands take turns in testing the novelty of the situations, initially improvising to bridge the awkwardness but then risking more and more. While the night out feels liberating, it ends up tearing painfully at their conservative personas.

results.title: Face/off
results.creator_credit: Douglas Reuter Productions, WCG Entertainment, David Permut, Barrie M Osborne, Terence Chang, Christopher Goosick and John Woo
results.brief_description: Acclaimed Hong Kong action director John Woo has created a delirious mix of spectacular gun battles, furious explosions and breathtaking stunts. John Travolta plays driven but anguished FBI agent Sean Archer, who is using the full force of his anti-terrorist unit to track down the psychotic criminal Castor Troy, energetically played by Nicolas Cage. Thinking he has finally killed Castor in a spectacular airport shootout, Archer is horrified to discover that he is in fact alive but in a coma. Undergoing a radical face-swapping procedure, Archer assumes Castor’s identity in an attempt to discover the Los Angeles location of a nerve gas bomb due to explode. When Castor awakens from his coma, he retaliates by infiltrating the real Archer’s life and destroying any evidence of the identity switch. Archer is thrust into a nightmare, where he must fight for his life and his family. This cat and mouse thriller was written by Mike Werb and Michael Colleary. Music by John Powell. Edited by Christian Wagner and Steven Kemper. Cinematography by Oliver Wood. Also stars Joan Allen, Alessandro Nivola, Gina Gershon, Dominique Swain and Nick Cassavetes.

results.title: Face to face: dealing with conflict
results.creator_credit: Educational Film Center and Agency for Instructional Television
results.brief_description: Highlights the need to be aware of one’s limitations and to know when to say “no”. An adolescent girl at high school takes on too much work on the local school magazine and as a result her school work suffers. Unable to handle her poor examination results, she lashes out angrily and irrationally at those around her. Raises issues regarding the need to accept responsibility for one’s actions and to be assertive as opposed to weak or aggressive.
